question: What force causes the planets in the solar system to orbit the Sun?

content.source_1: In a two-body system, an inverse-square central attraction F = G M m / r^2 can provide the inward (centripetal) force m v^2 / r needed to sustain a bound orbit at distance r around mass M.
content.source_2: The Sun contains about 99.8% of the Solar System’s mass, so its gravitational pull overwhelmingly dominates the first-order motion of the planets as small bodies bound to a central massive body.
content.source_3: The electromagnetic interaction is vastly stronger than gravity between charged particles (by ~10^36 in relative strength), and the Sun fills the heliosphere with a large-scale magnetic field carried by the ionized solar wind.
content.source_4: Planets and moons interact electromagnetically with the solar wind: they possess magnetospheres/ionospheres, can develop electrical potentials/charges, and support current systems that experience Lorentz forces and torques in the heliospheric magnetic field.
content.source_5: Kepler’s laws (elliptical orbits with the Sun at a focus; equal areas in equal times; P^2 ∝ a^3) are the natural consequence of motion under a central inverse-square attraction, matching planetary trajectories.
content.source_6: Non-gravitational influences such as solar radiation pressure, Poynting–Robertson drag, and electromagnetic interactions measurably perturb the paths of small bodies and spacecraft in interplanetary space.
